div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7206] ALEXANDRIA, WEDNESDAY, MAY 24, 1905. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: Orient-Pacific Line of Royal Mail Steamers.
div.p: REDUCED SUMMER FARES FROM MAY TO OCTOBER INCLUSIVE.
OUTWARDS to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. “Orotava" will leave Suez about July 28 | R.M.S "Ormuz" will leave Suez about August 11.
HOMEWARDS to NAPLES MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY
R.M.S. "Oroya" will leave Port Said about July 18 | R.M.S. “Ortona" will leave Port Said about August 1
Egyptian Government Officials allowed a rebate of 15% off the above fares.

Return tickets no longer issued, but passengers paying full fare in one direction allowed abatement of 1/3 fare back if return voyage be within 4 months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within 8 months of arrival.
Agents. Cairo:—Thos. Cook & Son. Alexandria : —R. J. Moss & Co.—For all information apply
Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT-SAID & PORT-TEWFIK (Suez) 31-12-904

OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, etc., and RANGOON. Departures from Suez.
S.S. Derbyshire 6,635 tons, leaves about July 20.
S.S. Lancashire 4,244 tons, leaves about August 3.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON. Departures from Port Said.
S.S. Worcestershire 7,160 tons, leaves about July 26.
S.S. Yorkshire 4,196 tons leaves about August 9,
FARES from Port Said to Marseilles £12.0.0, London £17.0.0, Colombo £32.10.0, Rangoon £37.10.0.
Agents Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS, 31-12-905

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
FAST BRITISH PASSENGER STEAMERS
GREECE - TURKEY LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.
div.head: PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.
div.p: Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
div.head: RED SEA LINE.
div.p: Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency. 31-12-904

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Monday, July 17, to be followed by S.S. Menes.
S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday l5th inst.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents. 26-12-905

S.S. ARRACAN 5800 Tons will leave PORT SAID about 20 for Liverpool

Alexandria, Port-Said, Suez, Luxor, Assuan, Haifa, & Khartum.
GENERAL RAILWAY AND STEAMSHIP AGENTS. BANKERS.
BAGGAGE AND FORWARDING AGENTS.
Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook’s Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT, Lowest Rates.
Best camp equipment in the country! 10 12-904

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL, ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: First-class Hotel. Situated in Rosetta Avenue, the finest quarter in the Town. Two mintes from Railway Station. Close to Conservatory and the Opera House. Lift. Electric Light Throughout. Perfect Sanitary Arragnements. Magnificent Ball, Reception, Reading, and Music Rooms. Bar and Smoking Room.
HENRI CHAMOULLEAU, Proprietor.
FINE TERRACE ON THE AVENUE. - SPLENDID GARDEN. - OMNIBUS MEET ALL TRAINS AND STEAMERS. 28-26

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for express to Paris, London, Naples, Rome. Arrival Trieste Wednesday noon connecting with Vienna Express (Trieste-Ostende through carriage) and expresses to Italy and Germany.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste

(Departures from Suez) To Aden, Bombay, Colombo, Penang, Singapore, Hong-Kong, Shanghai, Yokohama, Kobé about July 5 and August 4. To Aden, Karachi, and Bombay accelerated service about August 18. To Aden, Karachi, Bombay, Colombo, Madras, Rangoon, and Calcutta about July 20.

The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.
Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: MANCHURIA.
RUSSIANS OCCUPY SHAHOT-SE
FORCES ADVANCING SOUTH
div.p: St.Petersburg, May 23.

General Linievich reports that a Russian force occupied Shahot-se on the 20th inst. Another compelled the Japanese to evacuate Chantu-fu station on the 17th inst., and both forces continued to advance south. (Reuter.)

div.head: ADMIRAL BIRILEFF.
TO COMMAND PACIFIC FLEET.
div.p: St. Petersburg, May 23.
Admiral Birileff has been appointed to the command of the Balsic Float with the right of command over the army. (Havas.)
St. Petersburg, May 23.
Admiral Birileff has been appointed to the command of the Pacific fleet with independent powers. (Reuter.)

div.head: COTTON AS CONTRABAND.
GOVERNMENT ASKED TO PROTEST.
div.p: London, May 23.

Colonel Nolan has called the attention of the government to the decision with regard to the British S.S "Calchas” and asks that they should protest against the treatment of cotton as contraband of war. (Reuter.)

div.head: STRANGE BOW-STREET CASE.
THE PASSPORT TO RUSSIA.
div.p: London, May 23.

The well-known journalist Brailsford and the actor McCulloch were charged at Bow street with conspiring to obtain a passport to Russia purporting to be for McCulloch but actually handed to the Russian revolutionary who was killed by the bomb explosion of the 11th of March. The Solicitor-General, in prosecuting, described this as an offence of exceeding gravity, endangering the peaceful relations between Russia and Great Britain. The case was adjourned for a fortnight. (Reuter.)

div.head: GRAND DUKE SERGIUS'S ASSASSIN HANGED.
div.p: St. Petersburg, May 23.
Kalajeff, the assassin of the Grand Duke Sergius has been hanged. (Havas.)

div.head: TUREO-ROUMANIAN DIFFICULTY SETTLED
div.p: Bucharest, May 23.
The Turco-Roumanian difficulty has been settled in favor of Roumania. (Reuter.)

div.head: LYONS'S STRIKE ENDED.
div.p: Lions, May 28.
The strike is at an end. (Havas.)

div.head: DEATH OF FRENCH SCULPTOR.
div.p: Paris, May 23.
The sculptor Paul Dubois is dead (Havas.)

Paul Dubois, who was one of the greatest of modern sculptures, was born at Nogent-sur-Seine, July 18, 1829. He was destined by his father for the legal profession, but his artistic tastes constrained him to devote himself to sculpture, and he went to Paris to become the pupil of the sculptor Toussaint, with whom he remained three years. In 1859 he went to Italy, and in 1860 executed at Florence the model for "St. John a Child," which was finished at Rome, exhibited at the Salon of 1863, and is now at the Luxembourg, together with “A Florentine Singer of the Fiftienth Century." This last is in silvered bronze and thought its many reproductions in smaller size has become very popular. Other works which may be cited are the tomb of General'la Moriciere, one of the masterpieces of modern statuary (1878), which is at Nantes; and busts of Bonnat, Cabanel, Paul Baudry, Gounod, Pasteur (1890), and other celebrities. M. Dubois also studied painting, and had executed nine portraits and beautiful copies of old masters but was a very irregular contributor to the Salon exhibitions. In 1873 he was appointed keeper of the Luxembourg Museum, and director of the Ecole des Beaux-Arts, May 30, 1878. Elected a member of the Academie des Beaux-Arts in 1876, he was one of the Jury of Admission for the selection of sculpture at the Exposition of 1878. He was a grand officer of the Legion of Honour (1889).

div.head: CRICKET.
div.p: London, May 23.
M.C.C; beat Kent by 9 wickets. (Reuter.)

div.head: HOUSE OF COMMONS.
MONDAY'S “SCENE.”
MATTER NOW DROPPED.
div.p: London, May 23.

The scene in the House of Commons is without parallel in the history of the House. The speakers, chiefly Mr Lyttelton, were greeted with angry cries of "Bring in the Guards!” “Where are the police!” and by the blowing of police whistles. After Mr. Austen Chamberlain and Mr. Brodrick has sat down, Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman again appealed to Mr. Balfour declaring that by his silence he alone was responsible for the disturbance. This renewed the uproar and Mr. Balfour rose and severely rebuked the House for its unseemly behaviour. Never in his experience had it refused to listen to a Minister speaking for the Government, nor had the Opposition presumed to dictate the order of speeches. To-night's precedent, if followed, would absolutely ruin the Commons. Mr.Lyttelton again rose, but the storm burst with redoubled fury. The Deputy Speaker adjourned the House by virtue of the new rule reffering to a grave disorder. The prolongation of the scene is attributed to the fact that the Deputy-Speaker, who presided in consequence of the Speaker's illness, has no power to suspend individual Members.(Reuter.)
London, May 23.

House of Commons.- The House to-day was thronged, and Sir H. Campbell Bannerman and Mr. Balfour were received with extraordinary ovations on entering. Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman asked whether in view of the confusion created by the recent declarations of Ministers with reference to the fiscal question and the Colonial Conference, Mr. Balfour would fix a day for a vote of censure. Mr. Balfour said that two Ministers were prepared to clear up any confusion yesterday, when they wore prevented by the disgraceful proceedings which Sir H. Campbell-Bannerman did nothing to prevent. He had no objection to fixing a day provided he had an undertaking that the debate would be conducted with ordinary de ceney and fair play. The matter was then dropped. (Reuter.)

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Prince Aziz Pasha Hassan intends going to Bad Gastein shortly.
Prince Abbas Pasha Halim and Abani Pasha, Minister of War, came down from Cairo last night.

We regret to announce the death, which took place at Seville on the 19th inst, after a long and painful illness, of Mine Marguerite Eeman-van Moutenaeken, wife of Judge Albert Eeman, president of the Mansourah Mixed Tribunal.

Sheikh Muhamed Abdou, Grand Moufti of Egypt, is leaving for Europe on the 15th proxo. His religious duties will be performed by Hassan Pasha Assem during his absence. The Grand Moufti’s health is, we regret to state, not very good, and his medical advisers have ordered him to go for a change of air.
Mgr. Cyril VIII., Greek Catholic Patriarch of Egypt, is loaving Cairo to spend the summer atBamleh.

Kaimakam Drury Bey, Controller of the Port of Suskin, is staying at the San Stefano Hotel-Casino. He is studying the Ports and Lighthouses Administration with a view to the foundation of a similar administration for the Sudan ports.
Captain G. C. M. Hall, R. E., goods manager of the State Railways, will leave for England tomorrow.
The salary of Mr. Runel A. Colvin, the newly-appointed chief engineer to the Sudan Irrigation Service, will be L.E. 428 per annum.

The marriage of Mr. Claude J. Rolo to Miss Celine Piha, the daughter of M. and Mme Elie A. Piha Bey, was celebrated at the residence of Mr. Jacques Rolo at Rue de Corinthe, Alexandria, yesterday afternoon. There was a very large and fashionable attendance of wedding guests, including all the members of the Diplomatic and Consular Corps at Alexandria and all the leading representatives of Alexandria society. The Khedive was represented by his Chief Equerry, Lewa. Thurneyssen Pasha. The religious ceremony was performed by the Grand Rabbi of Alexandria. The wedding party afterwards adjourned to the garden, which presented a most animated spectacle. There were two buffets, one in the garden and the other in the house. An orchestra played a charming selection of airs in the garden and the guests did not leave until 8 o'clock.
BECK & CO’S PILSENER BEER
BREMEN.
Obtainable from every Respectable Firm In Cairo, Alexandria & the Sudan.
Otherwise apply to
V. J. FLEURENT, Cairo
F. MICALLEF, Sole Agent, 11 Bab Midan, Alexandria

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p: The Brindisi Mail will arrive at Alexandria this evening and will be distributed at the G P.O. at 7.10 a.m. tomorrow.
The Coptic Language.—Mr W. E. Crum has started classes in the Coptic language at the London University.
Native Killed. -A goods train ran over a native on the Customs quays yesterday, the man being killed on the spot.
Cyprus,-The May issue of the “Cyprus Journal” is full of interesting matter affecting the commerce and industries of the island.
Stray and Ownerless Dogs found in the Saida Zenab quarter of Cairo during to night and at dawn to-morrow will be poisoned by tho police.
Egyptian Estates, Limited.—The committee of the London Stock Exchange has granted a special settling day to the above company, which has been fixed for May 30.
The Sinai Expedition, which Professor Flinders Petrie undertook recently, is to be the subject of six lectures by the professor during this and next month at the London University.

Sudan Exploration.—The London Stock Exchange Committee has appointed May 30 as special settlingday for "Sudan Exploration", further issue of 58,834 shares of 10s. each, fully paid, Nos, 60,001 to 118,834.

Sharaki Land.—The scheme for extending the prohibition of Sharaki land irrigation in Upper and Lower Egypt has been submitted to the approbation of the Legislative Council prior to it being promulgated in the form of a Decree.

The Pilgrimage Enquiry.—The enquiry into the incidents, which occurred during the pilgrimage, is continuing. The evidence of the Emir el-Hag, the commandant of the soldiers accompanying the pilgrimage, and others has been heard.

Suez Canal.—On the 20th and 21st inst. 25 vessels passed through the Canal. Of these, 18 were British, 1 Russian, 4 German, 2 Dutch. The receipts for the two days were frs, 609,927.51, making the total from the 1st inst. frs. 6,617,704.16.

The Sais Sarcophagi.—The services of M. Moret have been engaged by the Government for two months in order to edit a part of the catalogue of the sarcophagi of the Sais dynasty. He has been appointed provisionally for this special duty at a salary of L.E. 33 per month.

An Interesting Visitor.—Considerable interest was recently aroused at Khartoum by the visit of Sheikh Mahomed Aly Omar Or, head of the Genilab Arabs, who live near Suakin and roam about over a large area between that port and Kassala. It was chiefly through his agency that Osma Digna was captured.

A. L M. & D. S.— The concert given last night at the San Stefamo Casino by the Alexandria Literary, Musical and Dramatic Society was an unqualified success, a large attendance being present and the programme affording great pleasure. Abundance of matter compels us to hold over our criticism of the concrrt till to-morrow.

The Summer Exodus.—Is it necessary to remind those who intend touring this summer how useful a knowledge of languages would be to them. The rapid and practical method of the Berlitz School can in a very short time give a sufficient knowledge of the language of the country in which one may be traveling. A free trial lesson will give ample proof. [Advt.]

Empire Day.—An open-air concert will be held at the Kasr-el-Nil Barracks at 9.30 this evening. M. F. Watson Ramsay, bandmaster of the 2nd Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, has arranged an exellent programme for the occasion, and a large audience is expected to be present. A holiday has been given to the pupils of the military schools throughout Egypt. At Alexandria the day will be celebrated at Mr. Alderson’s Garden in Bulkeley.

French Fete.—A meeting of the members of the French colony in Cairo was held on Monday evening to elect a committee for the organization of the fete which takes place yearly on the 14th of July. The following members were elected : MM. J. Barois, B. Muller, Comte de Serionne, Paul Oziol, A. Leroux, L. Pitelle, Maitre J. B. Tramoni, Dr. Brossard, C. Battenberg, Tourneron Bey, Conin Pasteur, G. Vayssie, A. Bianchi, Paul Manse, Philippoteanx, H. Cernadou, Souter, A. Derroja, Proutelle, G. Privat.

Sailors and Soldiers' Institute.—A concert will be given at the institute to-morrow evening, commencing at 8 o'clock. The programme is attractive and includes the names of Mrs. R. N. Gamble, Mrs. Gordon, Miss MunGavin, Miss M. K. Gibson, Mr. H. M. Dodwell, Mr. O.S. Heaton, Prof. Rizzitano, Gunner S. Hall, Private Russell, and Drummer Pearce. Songs, recitations, pisnoforte, violin, and mandoline solos, a performance on the bells, and an exhibition of club swinging should ensure a pleasant evening being passed. There will be no charge for admission, but a collection will be taken at the door.

div.head: ASSIOUT FREE OF LOCUSTS.
NO EGGS DISCOVERED.
div.p: Assiout Moudirieh is now pronounced entirely free from locusts. A careful watch is being exercised in this and in the other provinces of Upper Egypt, but no eggs have been discovered anywhere except in one district of Minieh. The inhabitants have responded with great alacrity to the orders of the local authorities.

div.head: THE COTTON WORM.
div.p: The seriousness of the present situation can be grasped when we state that the actual loss due to the worm during the cotton season last year is estimated at between 1,000,000l. and 2,000,000l. at least.

The life-history of the worm is as follows :amp; About the beginning of June the moth lays eggs (about 300) on a leaf near the bottom of the plant. These are easily soon on examination. The period of incubation is from three to four days. The young worms begin to feed on the leaf on which they are hatched. They grow very rapidly, and in a few days spread over the entire plant. After feeding (from 18 to 22 days), the worms burrow into the soil, construct cells, and pass the pupa stage (8 to 10 days). The moths then hatch out and commence laying again. The whole life-history is thus from 30 to 40 days, depending to a certain extent on climatic conditions. In July, therefore, we bare a second brood, followed by a thud in August, after which the worms find food elsewhere. It is clear that the pest can be most satisfactorily attacked by picking the leaves on which the eggs are found. When the worms have spread over the plant, they eat the young buds, flowers, leaves, &c., and it is impossible to do much. Fields have to be examined every few days when eggs are being laid. It is evident that the more thoroughly the June brood is kept in check, the less severe will subsequent generations be.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive came to Ras el Tin Palace today from Montazah. Tomorrow, at about 10 a.m., a his Highiness will visit the Mosques of Abou El Abbas,Yakut El Arahi,and El Abasiri, where religious instruction is given.
The Khedive will leave to-morrow afternoon by the Austrian Lloyd's S.S. "Amphitrite” for Constantinople, en route to London.
Boutros Pasha Ghali, Minister for Foreign Affairs, will probably accompany the Khedive on his visit to London.
"Al Lewa" says that on the occasion of the Khedive’s visit to Constantinople, his Highness will ask the Sultan to allow him to extend the Mariout railway line as far as the borders of Tripoli.

div.head: BEHERA COMPANY.
div.p: The Behera Company is evidently taking advantage of the decision of the Egyptian Government to suspend all important land sales in order to dispose of large blocks of its own land. A notice of a very important land sale by this company will be found on page 4.

div.head: "LONDON GAZETTE."
div.p: The following extracts from the "London Gazette,” dated 16 May, 1905, are of interest:

Princess Charlotte of Wales's (Royal Berkshire Regiment). — Second Lieutenant L. W. Bird to be Lieutenant, vice H. H. Shott, D.S.O., seconded for service under the Colonial Office. Dated 15 February, 1905.
Second Lieutenant L. C. Howard is removed from the Service for absence without leave. Dated 17 May, 1905.

div.head: MARIANNE HUGHES FUND.
div.p: The annual meeting of the committee of thd Marianne Hughes Fund was held at the British Agency, Cairo, on the 22nd inst, at 6.30 p.m. There were present the Earl and Countess of Cromer, Miss Lassel, matron of Kasr-el-Ainy Hospital, Dr. Wilson, Mr. Elliot, and Dr. Madden, hon. secretary and treasurer.

The hon. secretary presented the accounts for 1904, which were approved, and reported the purchase of a new carriage for the sisters of Kasr-el-Ainy, and, also, the gift of a horse from Major Blunt, Director of Supplies, E. A., to whom the warmest thanks of the committee are due. During the past season 20 nurses were enrolled on the register, which is kept by the matron of the Anglo-American Hospital, Cairo, to whom applications for private nurses should be made. In conclusion, the committee wish to thank Mr. Rowlatt for his kindness in again auditing the accounts of the fund.
The following is the statement of accounts of the Marianne Hughes Fund for 1904:—

p.p: Balance to credit on Dec. 31st 1903 7,203 8 Interest on £1,800 Cairo WaterCo’s 4% Debentures .............. 7,002.5 14,2068

div.head: EXPENDITURE.
P.T.
div.p: Matron’s honorarium ............. 1,400.0 Summer leave to Sisters.………. 2,437.5 Incidental Summer expenses..... 967.5 G. Heath and Son New collar and repairs 213.0 New carriage ..... 5,850.0 ------ 6,063.0 Book for Register of Nurses….. 16.0 Balance to credit on Dec. 31s ,1904 3,322 3 14,206.8

div.head: ATTEMPTED MURDER IN MOHAMED ALY SQUARE.
div.p: This morning, at about 10.30 ’o'clock, a serious outrage took place in Mohamed Aly square, Alexandria, which resulted in grave injuries to Ahmed Khalil, late consular janissary to the American consular agency and at present bowab to St. Mark's Small Building. While the man was on an errand and was walking through the square to collect some money , an unknown person rushed up to him and folded him to the ground with a sharp instrument,. evidently some iron weapon. His upper lip was cut clean open and a gaping wound extends under the nose. The aggressor at once made off, leaving his victim lying in a pool of blood. The injured man has been taken to the Government Hospital. He is quite unable to identify his would-be assassin, who fortunately did not plunge the weapon far enough into the man's mouth to inflict fatal injuries to the throat. It is strange that such a bloodthirsty outrage could have been committed in Mohamed Aly square, which was crowded with people, at that hour, and the assassin have escaped scot free.

div.head: NYAM-NYAM EXPEDITION.
div.p: It appears that Yambio, the Nyam-Nyam chief, whose death we announced in our Saturday’s issue, had been the mainstay of the whole revolt, and that from the first his people wanted to come in, but were kept back by him. He ruled his people with extreme severity, his only punishment was death, and this was meted out frequently for the slightest offence. Large numbers of women and girls were found closely confined and jealously guarded in his village. All were released and sent book to their villages whenever possible. Among the trophies captured was the Sultan's great war drum. It stands four feet high, is cut out of a single tree trunk, and is carved to represent a buffalo. At Yambio's funeral there was no great display of grief, and on this being pointed out by a British officer, an Arab-speaking native answered “No ; they are not sorry, for if Yambio had died a natural death and had been buried by his own people, least 300 of them would have been slain at the same time. "After establishing posts throughout the whole district, and explaining the object of the Government, the remainder of the force returned to Waw at the end of March. The expedition was an unqualified success, and reflects great credit on Major Boulnois and all the officers under his command. On the way back one of the officers had rather a narrow escape. A leopard he had wounded badly came straight for him, and though hit again in the neck, was not finished off before it had bitten him deep in the arm and crunched the right hand with its powerful jaws.

div.head: THE "HANDY MAN" IN THE SUDAN.
div.p: A number of naval men are at the present time doing excellent work in the Sudan. Besides a number of Marine Artillery sergeants there are no lets than five officers of the Royal Navy in the service of the Sudan Government. This number is composed of Miralai Bond Bey, Engineer, Commander, R.N., Director of Steamers and Boats ; Kaimakam Fell, Lieutenant, R.N., Bahr-el-Ghazal Special Service : Kaimakam Drury Bey, Lieutenant, R.N., controller Sudan Ports, Suskin , Bimbashi Bayldon, R.N., Bahr-el-Ghazal Special Service ; Bimbashi Scott Hill, R.N., Assistant-Director, Steamers and Boats. The Marine Artillery sergeants include Messrs. Sebright, Evans, Knowles, Sears, Muller, and others, all of whom are doing very good work in the service of the Sudan Government.

div.head: THE UPPER NILE.
div.p: Addressing the Royal Geographical Society on Monday week on “The Nile Province of Western Uganda," Lient.Col C. Delme Radcliffe, M.V.O., said when he took over the civil and military charge of the Nile District from Col. Martyr he found the parapet and ditches of Emin Pasha's old station at Wadelai, on the left bank, in a fair state of preservation, though the buildings had disappeared. The natives remembered Emin well. Of Gordon only a few natives seemed to know anything, though most of those living near the river had heard of “Godun," as he was called, and an interesting relic had been secured in the shape of an Austrian bentwood chair, which Gordon had given to the chief Gimorro. The chair was to be seen in a room adjoining the lecture theatre.

div.head: NAVAL NOTES.
(From our Correspondent).
Suez, Tuesday.
div.p: H.M.’s cruisers “Canopus" and “Goliath” arrived at Suez this morning from Port Said
and are now coaling in the Suez Bay. They will both sail for the China station next Friday to relieve H.M.S. "Ocean" and “Centurion."

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Cunard S.S. “Pavia" sailed for Liver-pool yesterday afternoon with a full cargo, including 1,661 bales cotton and 10,664 bags onions.
The Khedivial Mail S.S. “El Kahira” will leave Alexandria on Saturday and Port-Said on Sunday for Jaffa, Caiffa, Beyrout, Tripoli,’ Mersina, Alexandretta, Larnaos and Limassol.

div.head: NOTES FROM POUR SAID.
UNSAFE BUILDINGS
(From Our Correspondent).
div.p: Port Said, Tuesday.

Yesterday, for the second time during the past month, a certain house situated in the Greek quarter, not for from the bazaar, caught fire. The house if built of wood and was much damaged. No lives were lost end the fire was extinguished without the assistance of the Fire Brigade. There are many blocks of this class of wooden building in Port Said, which were constructed soon after the opening of the canal and arc now very unsafe and insanitary.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL COMPANY '
div.p: In connection with the coming changes in the administration of the Suez Canal Company, -changes rendered necessary by the retirement of M. Tillier,—I understand that Sir H. Austin Lee, K.C.B., etc., the resident British director of the company in Paris, is to come to Egypt in November on a special mission. Mr Hughes, the recently appointed director, and possibly one other British member, on the board, will accompany him. Preparations to receive these gentlemen are being discussed.

div.head: NAVAL NOTES.
div.p: At dawn yesterday H.M.S. "Canopus” arrived from Portsmouth and entered the canal at once, just as H.M.S. “Goliath" arrived in from sea. The latter vessel only remained in the port, two hours and then proceeded. The original idea was that they were both to coal and provision here, but their great draught of water (26’.2”) made that impossible.

div.head: A LUGUBRIOUS FIND.
div.p: On Saturday morning last the body of a newly born male child was discovered behind the offices of the Orient Line. The greater part of the child's abdomen had been apparently devoured by dogs. The police are engaged on an enquiry, with so for no result.

div.head: RAILWAY ACCIDENT.
div.p: At Kantars, to-day, a native railway employe, in attempting to board the up train, which was passing at the tune, slipped and fall between the rails, the entire train passing over his body. The tram was sent back to Kantara soon after its arrival here in order that the officials interested could assist at the enquiry, which was held at noon.

div.head: EGYPTIAN MINING.
GOLD AND GEM SYNDICATE
div.p: The secretary writes: — "The company's engineer, Mr. John James,reports that developments on the property are proceeding satisfactorily. Sikait Emerald mines—The new shaft to cut the Emerald measures below water level has been temporarily suspended, owing to the impossibility of obtaining a regular supply of explosives in the country. Hangallya Gold mines— Water has been struck in the new water shaft. The main drive at Wady level is being continued on the lode, which it will be remembered assayed 11 ozs of gold per ton. The tramway is now completed op to the face. New discoveries—Two gold mines have been located, bringing up the total number of gold mines at present discovered to 21. One of these by pan assay gives 1/1/2 oz of gold per ton. It is described by Mr. James as the largest yet discovered, with enormous tailings heaps. Copper— A few miles south-west of Sherm Sheikh harbour Mr. James has located a virgin copper field of great extent, containing immense lodes hitherto unworked by the ancients. Samples of carbonate are taken from the surface have been assayed in London, which give‘14 per cent of copper."

div.head: UM RUS MINE
div.p: The second monthly crushing of the Um Rus Mine is decidedly encouraging. The production was 489oz. of gold, as compared with 351oz. for April, the average yield per ton working out at 20jewt. (including 3dwt. in the stored tailings), as compared with 184dwt. Important also is the striking at the lowest level of a vein 22in. wide, and assaying 33dwt to the ton. There is satisfactory news also from the Atallah Mine of the Central Egypt Exploration Company, and a few more favorable developments will serve to neutralize the North Nile Valley affair. There is room for-much expansion in the Egyptian market, provided the mining industry shows that it is good for something, and the strong hand of the Government is there to prevent gross abuses.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA CAB-STANDS.
div.p: "Enquirer” writes:—I wish to understand the meaning of certain excellent arrangements evidently formulated by the officials of the Gouvernorst of Alexandria, but which appear to be words only, as no one needs the instructions. I refer to the "writing on the wall" here and there stating that "there is room here for a stand of 4 cabs and in others for 6, and so on." I have never yet found any cabs taking up their positions on these legalized stands but crawlers are still crawling and others place their carriages and horses half across the end of a street so as to be seen down the whole of it, to the great inconvenience of those turning into these streets when the abuggies are begged to "kasskiss” and get out of the way. In the early morning no cabs are to be found down the whole length of Rosetta-road, which is a long one, and this is a great inconvenience to people who do not keep their own carriages. The same thing occurs late in the evening. If the “writing on the wall" has any in it why are there instructions treated as null and void.
